First, we need to determine the time period in which each work was written. The Canterbury Tales was written by Geoffrey Chaucer in Middle English in the late 14th century, between 1387 and 1400. One Thousand and One Nights (also known as The Arabian Nights) is a collection of Middle Eastern and South Asian folk tales compiled during the Islamic Golden Age, believed to have been written between the 8th and 14th centuries.

From this information, we can see that The Canterbury Tales was written after One Thousand and One Nights. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) no.

First, we need to determine the dates when both works were written. The Canterbury Tales is a collection of stories written by Geoffrey Chaucer in the late 14th century, between 1387 and 1400. One Thousand and One Nights, also known as Arabian Nights, is a collection of Middle Eastern and South Asian stories and folk tales compiled in Arabic during the Islamic Golden Age, most likely between the 8th and 14th centuries. 

Therefore, we can conclude that One Thousand and One Nights was written before The Canterbury Tales. As a result, the answer to the question is (B) no.

The Canterbury Tales is a collection of stories written by Geoffrey Chaucer in the 14th century, while One Thousand and One Nights (also known as Arabian Nights) is a collection of Middle Eastern and South Asian stories from the Islamic Golden Age, compiled over several centuries. 
Next, we need to verify the chronological order of when they were written. Chaucer's work was completed in the late 1300s, while the earliest known surviving Arabic manuscript of One Thousand and One Nights dates to the early 15th century. Therefore, it can be concluded that One Thousand and One Nights was written after The Canterbury Tales, making the answer (B) no.
